sn52.9:4.1: At one time Venerables Anuruddha and Sāriputta were staying near Vesālī, in Ambapālī’s Wood.
sn52.9:4.2: Then in the late afternoon, Sāriputta came out of solitude, went to Anuruddha,
sn52.9:5.1: “Reverend Anuruddha, your faculties are so very clear, and your complexion is pure and bright.
sn52.9:5.2: What kind of meditation are you usually practicing these days?”
sn52.9:5.3: “These days, reverend, I usually meditate with my mind firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn52.9:5.5: I meditate by observing an aspect of the body …
sn52.9:5.8: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn52.9:5.9: These days I usually meditate with my mind firmly established in these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn52.9:5.10: A mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has lived the spiritual life, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their purpose, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through final knowledge—usually meditates with their mind firmly established in these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”
sn52.9:6.1: “We’re so fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate,
sn52.9:6.2: to have heard such a dramatic statement directly from Venerable Anuruddha.”
